prevtext:
\preprint{UUITP-01/16}
~\\
\title{The force awakens --- the 750 GeV diphoton excess at the LHC from a varying electromagnetic coupling}

\author{Ulf Danielsson}
\email{ulf.danielsson@physics.uu.se}


\author{Rikard Enberg}
\email{rikard.enberg@physics.uu.se}


\author{Gunnar Ingelman}
\email{gunnar.ingelman@physics.uu.se}


\author{Tanumoy Mandal}
\email{tanumoy.mandal@physics.uu.se}
\affiliation{Department of Physics and Astronomy, Uppsala University, Box 516, SE-751 20 Uppsala, Sweden}

\date{\today}

\begin{abstract}

We show that the recent 750 GeV diphoton excess observed at the LHC may be explained by the production of a scalar of the type involved in Bekenstein's framework for varying-$\alpha$ theories, with the difference that the scalar in our model has a large mass. The model has only two free parameters, the mass of the scalar and the scale of this new physics, which are fixed by the LHC excess to 750~GeV and $1.5-2$~TeV, respectively. We discuss collider and cosmology aspects of the model, and give predictions for future LHC searches. In particular, the scalar is dominantly produced by quark-antiquark fusion in association with a photon or a fermion pair. In addition, it can be produced in the $s$-channel in photon-photon fusion. Its dominating decay is to diphotons, but it also has a large three-body decay to a fermion pair and a photon, which provides an interesting search channel with a dilepton-photon resonance at 750 GeV. We also comment on the possibility that the new physics is related to extra dimensions or string theory.

\end{abstract}

\pacs{XXX}

\keywords{LHC, Diphoton, Varying $\alpha$-model}



\maketitle


\section{Introduction}
\label{sec:intro}

Recently both the ATLAS and the CMS collaborations reported excesses in
the diphoton invariant mass distribution around 750 GeV~\cite{ATLAS:2015dxe,CMS:2015dxe}
based on the 13 TeV data from Run 2. The excesses have local significances of 3.9$\sigma$ for ATLAS and 2.0$\sigma$ for CMS for a relatively large width of the resonance (up to 45~GeV for ATLAS) or 3.6$\sigma$ for ATLAS and 2.6$\sigma$ for CMS for a narrow width resonance. Thus ATLAS has a slightly larger significance for a large width while CMS has a slightly larger significance for a narrow width. Including the look-elsewhere effect, the global significances are further reduced. The mass of the resonance is near 750 GeV, which is the value we will assume in this paper. The results are thus not statistically significant enough to draw definite conclusions, but are nevertheless very interesting to try to understand from a theoretical perspective.

In this paper we propose to explain the observed excess by a massive scalar that decays into a pair of photons. This scalar is associated with a model for a space-time varying electromagnetic coupling constant, constructed more than thirty years ago by Jacob Bekenstein~\cite{Bekenstein:1982eu,*Bekenstein:2002wz}.
Bekenstein's model is the first consistent such model---it is Lorentz, gauge and time-reversal invariant and respects causality. The original motivation was to accommodate possible variations of the fine-structure constant over cosmological scales, but despite careful searches such variations have not been detected, see e.g.~\cite{Uzan:2010pm}. 

In string theory all couplings are associated with scalar fields, called moduli, and are thus subject to variations. The excitations of these fields are typically very heavy and as a consequence the couplings will be locked to essentially constant values, given by the specific compactification scenario, see e.g.~\cite{Zagermann:2011asa} for a discussion. The Bekenstein model is not derived from string theory, but we consider it the simplest consistent scenario for associating couplings with scalar fields.

In this paper we assume that the diphoton excess can be explained by a massive scalar of the type appearing in the Bekenstein model. However, with such a high mass the fine-structure constant will remain constant throughout most of the history of the universe and no deviations would have been detectable so far.\footnote{The new scalar should also be investigated as a candidate for the inflaton. The quadratic contribution to the potential, with the 750 GeV mass, cannot be used for inflation, but one might consider higher order terms providing a useful shape.} The diphoton excess would then be the first hint that the fine-structure constant can vary if the energy is high enough.

As we will see, our model is qualitatively different from many proposed explanations of the LHC diphoton excess (see e.g.\ \cite{Harigaya:2015ezk,*Buttazzo:2015txu,*Franceschini:2015kwy,*DiChiara:2015vdm,*Gupta:2015zzs,*Falkowski:2015swt,*Berthier:2015vbb}) in that the resonance is not produced in the $s$-channel, but always together with either a photon, or with a dijet or dilepton pair (some recent papers discuss similar not pure $s$-channel processes, see e.g.~\cite{Knapen:2015dap,*Chala:2015cev,*Bernon:2015abk,*Kim:2015ron}). It may be, however, that the extra particles escape detection so that the production looks like an $s$-channel process in the detector.
Moreover, the production in our model is dominantly due to quark-antiquark fusion, with the gluon-gluon fusion production mode loop-suppressed in comparison to the quark-antiquark mode. Finally, no additional particles apart from the scalar are introduced. For other recent work on explaining the LHC excess, 
see~\cite{Mambrini:2015wyu,

This paper is organized as follows. In Section \ref{sec:model} we introduce the model and derive the interactions of the new scalar. In Section \ref{sec:PDLHC} and Section \ref{sec:LHCdata} we discuss the phenomenology of the model, and through detailed numerical comparison with LHC data we extract the values of the two parameters in the model, resulting in a possible interpretation of the LHC diphoton excess as resulting from a scalar of the Bekenstein type. In Section \ref{sec:conclusions} we conclude by considering the results in a larger context.



\section{The model}
\label{sec:model}

In the Bekenstein model \cite{Bekenstein:1982eu,*Bekenstein:2002wz} the variation of the coupling constant $e$ is derived from an action that reduces to electromagnetism for constant coupling. It is assumed that the space-time variation of the electromagnetic coupling is given by $e = e_0 \epsilon(x)$, where $\epsilon(x)$ is a scalar field with dynamics given by the kinetic term

nexttext:
To keep our notation as explicit as possible we define ${\widehat{F}_{\mu
u}}={\partial_\mu} A_
u - {\partial_
u} A_\mu$, and introduce a scalar field $\varphi$ such that $\epsilon = e^\varphi$. We will be assuming small fields, working at lowest order, and therefore write  $\epsilon \simeq 1+\varphi$, and keep only terms linear in $\varphi$. We then find, for the kinetic term of the electromagnetic field, that ${F_{\mu
u}}{F^{\mu
u}} = {\widehat{F}_{\mu
u}}{\widehat{F}^{\mu
u}} + 4 \, {\partial_\mu}\varphi \, A_
u  {\widehat{F}^{\mu
u}} $. Finally, we define a new field $\phi=\varphi \Lambda$ so that all fields have their usual mass dimensions. In this way we find a  Lagrangian for electromagnetism plus the scalar field given by
prevtext: where $\Lambda$ is an energy scale. It is assumed that the field $\epsilon$ multiplies the electric charge $e$ everywhere in the Lagrangian of the model. Specifically, this means that $eA_\mu$ is everywhere replaced by $e_0 \epsilon A_\mu$. Gauge invariance, and invariance with respect to a rescaling of $\epsilon$, then requires that the field strength tensor be given by

nexttext:
It is shown in~\cite{Bekenstein:1982eu}, see also \cite{Magueijo:2001ir}, that one through a partial use of the equation of motion for $F_{\mu \nu}$ can map the theory to a new theory where the scalar only couples through $\frac{1}{2\Lambda} \phi {\widehat{F}_{\mu\nu}}{\widehat{F}^{\mu\nu}} $, without any coupling between the scalar and the fermions.  This  theory gives the same results for cosmological purposes, which was the focus of these papers. When it comes to the cross sections of interest to us the theories are inequivalent, and we here consider the original action due to Bekenstein.

Because of the definition of $e$, the new scalar field $\phi$ will in addition to the interaction in Eq.~(\ref{eq:scalarlagr}) couple to all electrically charged fields. The coupling of the electromagnetic field to charged fermions is obtained from the covariant derivative, which is given by $D_\mu = {\partial_\mu} - i e Q A_\mu$, where $Q$ is the charge of the coupled field, and $e=e_0\epsilon$ so that $D_\mu = {\partial_\mu} - i e_0 Q A_\mu - i e_0 Q (\phi/\Lambda) A_\mu$.
If we now define $\widehat D_\mu = {\partial_\mu}- i e_0 Q A_\mu$ as the more familiar covariant derivative of electromagnetism,
the gauge invariant kinetic term for fermions is given by

nexttext:
The final interaction of $\phi$ to consider is the coupling to $W^\pm$ bosons, which is obtained by inserting $eA_\mu=e_0\epsilon A_\mu$ in the electroweak gauge kinetic term written in terms of the mass eigenstates. The resulting terms to lowest order in the electric coupling are shown below in Eq.~(\ref{eq:Lag}).

As we have described above, this model has been used as a framework for a space-time varying fine-structure constant with a massless or very light scalar field $\phi$. We will now add one new ingredient: a mass term for the scalar field with $M_\phi\sim 750$~GeV. The energy cost of moving $\phi$ away from its minimum will then be very large for energies $\lesssim M_\phi$, so that $\alpha_\text{EM}$ will have negligible variation.

To get the Lagrangian in its final form, let us now drop the hats on the above expressions, so that from now on,
${F_{\mu\nu}}$ is the standard field strength tensor. Collecting all terms, we then have the Lagrangian of our model

nexttext:
The expressions for the other decay modes are more complicated due to the massive particles in the three-body phase space, and we compute the partial widths of those modes numerically.
Apart from these
modes, there are other subdominant four-body decay modes ({\it e.g.} $\phi\to \gm \psi^{+}\psi^{-*}\to
\gm\gm \psi^{+}\psi^{-}$) possible for $\phi$.
In Table~\ref{tab:PWBR}, we show the partial widths and branching
ratios (BR) of $\phi$ into its two, three and four body decay modes for $\Lm=1$ TeV, calculated using 
{\sc MadGraph5}.
It is important to note that the branching ratios of $\phi$ are independent of $\Lm$.
From Table~\ref{tab:PWBR}, we can see that $\phi\to\gm\gm$ is the dominant decay mode and this mode has a branching ratio
of about 70\%. Due to the large branching in the diphoton mode, $\phi$ might be a good candidate to explain the
recent 750 GeV diphoton excess at the LHC. Moreover, the nonobservation of any excess expected in other channels from a SM-like
scalar can also be explained as other decays of $\phi$ are not SM-like. To confirm the presence of $\phi$
or to set a limit on $\Lm$, we need dedicated analyses for other important channels that are not yet searched for at colliders.

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
Decay Mode & $\phi\to \gm\gm$ & $\phi\to \gm ff(jj)$ & $\phi\to \gm\gm ff$ & $\phi\to \gm WW$ & $\phi\to \gm\gm WW$ & Total \\
\hline
Width (GeV) & 8.393 & 2.672 (1.505) & 0.610 & 0.447 & 0.022 & 12.14 \\
\hline
BR (\%) & 69.12 & 22.00 (12.39) & 5.02 & 3.68 & 0.18 & - \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
\caption{The partial widths and branching ratios of $\phi$ for $M_{\phi}=750$ GeV. The widths are proportional to $\Lm^{-2}$ and are here given for $\Lm=1$ TeV, whereas the BRs are independent
of $\Lm$. Here, $f$ includes all SM charged fermions and $j$
denotes jets of ``light" quarks, including $b$. The four-body final states are non-negligible
corrections to the three-body modes.}
\label{tab:PWBR}
\end{table}

\subfloat[]{\includegraphics[height=3cm,width=3cm]{figures/qq2hpa1}\label{fig:qq2hpa1}}\hspace{0.25cm}

\caption{Sample Feynman diagrams of the production of $\phi$ at the LHC.}
\label{fig:FDpp2hpx}
\end{figure}

\begin{table}[!ht]
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
Production mode & $\phi\gm$ & $\phi\gm j$ & $\phi\gm jj$ & $\phi jj$ & $\gm\gm\to\phi$ & $\phi\ell\ell$ & $\phi\gm W$ & $\phi\gm WW$ & $\phi\gm\gm$ \\
\hline
CS@8TeV (fb)  & 2.339 & 1.161 & 0.513 & 4.622 & 30.84 & 0.017 & 0.064 & 0.176 & 0.026 \\
\hline
CS@13TeV (fb) & 10.63 & 6.486 & 3.439 & 15.15 & 77.59 & 0.081 & 0.577 & 4.847 & 0.140 \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
\caption{Partonic cross sections of various production channels of $\phi$ for $\Lm=1$ TeV computed at renormalization ($\mu_R$)
and factorization ($\mu_F$) scales $\mu_R=\mu_F=M_{\phi}=750$ GeV for LHC at  8 and 13 TeV. These cross
sections are computed using CTEQ6L1 PDFs by applying some basic generation level cuts as defined in Eq.~(\ref{eq:cut}).
Here, $j$ denotes light jets including $b$-jet and $\ell$ includes $e^{\pm}$ and $\mu^{\pm}$. In the $\gm\gm\to\phi$ mode, the
two initial $\gm$s come from photon PDFs of proton. Note that all signal cross sections scale as $\Lambda^{-2}$.}
\label{tab:CS}
\end{table}

In Fig.~\ref{fig:FDpp2hpx}, we show a few sample Feynman diagrams of the two main production
channels of $\phi$ at the LHC.
Unlike the $gg$ initiated SM-like Higgs boson production, these channels are
induced by a $qq$ initial state.
Therefore, to produce a TeV-scale $\phi$ one would get comparatively bigger contributions due to quark-PDFs
at high-$x$ than gluon-PDF. In Table~\ref{tab:CS}, we present the partonic cross sections of
various production modes of $\phi$ for the 8 and 13 TeV LHC for $\Lm=1$ TeV.
To compute these cross sections we apply
the following basic kinematical cuts at the generation level wherever they are applicable.

\be
\label{eq:cut}
p_T(x)>25~{\rm GeV};~~|\eta(x)|<2.5;~~\Dl R(x,y)>0.4~~~{\rm where}~~x,y\equiv \{\gm,\ell,j\}
\ee

The inclusive $pp\to\phi\gm+{\rm jets}$, $pp\to\phi jj$ and $pp\to\phi pp$ are the three main production
modes of $\phi$. The exclusive production of $\phi$ {\it i.e.} $pp\to\phi pp$,
where two forward protons are tagged, is an interesting process to search for, but this is beyond
the scope of this paper (this production mode has been considered in \cite{Fichet:2015vvy,Csaki:2015vek,Anchordoqui:2015jxc}, for models very different from ours).


\section{Comparison to the LHC data}
\label{sec:LHCdata}


To estimate the inclusive $pp\to\phi\gm$ signal without double counting, we use the
MLM matching prescription used in {\sc MadGraph5} to match matrix element partons with the parton shower.
Our inclusive signal includes up to two jets and we generate
it by combining the following processes,

\be
\left. \begin{array}{lclcl}
pp &\to &(\phi\ \gm) 		&\to & \gm\gm{\raisebox{1.5ex}{\hspace{{-2.5}ex}$\frown$\relax}}\ \gm\,,\\
pp &\to &(\phi\ \gm j)		&\to & \gm\gm{\raisebox{1.5ex}{\hspace{{-2.5}ex}$\frown$\relax}}\ \gm j\,,\label{eq:match}\\
pp &\to &(\phi\ \gm jj)  	&\to & \gm\gm{\raisebox{1.5ex}{\hspace{{-2.5}ex}$\frown$\relax}}\ \gm jj\,.
\end{array}\right\}
\ee
where we set the matching scale $Q_{cut}=30$ GeV. Here, the curved connection above two photons
signify that they come from the decay of $\phi$. The matched cross section of the inclusive
(up to 2-jets) $pp\to\phi\gm+{\rm jets}$ process is roughly 10 (2) fb for 13 (8) TeV LHC and
includes the $\phi\to\gm\gm$ BR.
The two photons coming from $\phi$-decay
are relatively hard compared to the third photon. In Figs.~\ref{fig:PTph1} and \ref{fig:PTph2}, we
show the transverse momentum ($p_T$) distributions of the first and second hardest photons respectively. Since
they come from the decay of a particle with mass 750 GeV, the $p_T$ distributions of them roughly peak
around 375 GeV. We show the $p_T$ distribution of the third hardest photon in Fig.~\ref{fig:PTph3}
and we can see that this distribution is relatively softer than the $p_T$ of the two hardest photons.
Therefore, when we construct the invariant mass ($M$) of two hardest photons, the third photon
would not contaminate much. As a result, we observe a sharp peak around 750 GeV in the invariant mass distribution of the first and second hardest photons. This has been demonstrated in Fig.~\ref{fig:IMphph}.

\begin{figure}[!ht]
\subfloat[]{\includegraphics[width=6cm,height=5cm,trim={0 1.5cm 0 1cm},clip]{figures/PTph1}\label{fig:PTph1}}\hspace{0.5cm}
\subfloat[]{\includegraphics[width=6cm,height=5cm,trim={0 1.5cm 0 1cm},clip]{figures/PTph2}\label{fig:PTph2}}\\
\subfloat[]{\includegraphics[width=6cm,height=5cm,trim={0 1.5cm 0 1.5cm},clip]{figures/PTph3}\label{fig:PTph3}}\hspace{0.5cm}
\subfloat[]{\includegraphics[width=6cm,height=5cm,trim={0 1.5cm 0 1.5cm},clip]{figures/IMphph}\label{fig:IMphph}}
\caption{Transverse momentum ($p_T$) and invariant mass ($M$) distributions of the selected photons by applying selection cuts used by 13 TeV CMS~\cite{CMS:2015dxe} analysis for
the inclusive $\phi\gm+{\rm jets}$ channel. The $p_T$ distributions of the three $p_T$-ordered photons
shown in (a), (b) and (c) respectively. In (d) we show the invariant mass distribution of the two hardest photons.}
\label{fig:dist}
\end{figure}

The experimental searches for a high mass diphoton resonance, where the signal is an $s$-channel
spin-0 or spin-2 resonance decaying to diphoton generally demand exactly two selected photons with no selected jet, whereas for inclusive diphoton resonance searches, one keeps events with at least two selected photons
and any number of selected jets. All these searches are optimized for $s$-channel resonances decaying to
two photons. Although there is no $s$-channel resonance production of $\phi$ present in our case,
the two important production channels of $\phi$ {\it viz.}
inclusive $pp\to\phi\gm\to 3\gm$ and $pp\to\phi jj\to\gm\gm jj$ contribute most to the ATLAS~\cite{ATLAS:2015dxe} and CMS~\cite{CMS:2015dxe} analyses.

Now, we want to investigate how selection cut efficiencies depend on the different selection 
criteria imposed on the number of photons and jets.
In Table~\ref{tab:CEhpa}, we show cut efficiencies for different selection
criteria on the number of photons and jets for the inclusive $pp\to\phi\gm\to 3\gm$ and $pp\to\phi jj\to\gm\gm jj$ channels at the 13 TeV LHC.


We roughly employ the selection cuts used by ATLAS~\citep{ATLAS:2015dxe} and CMS~\citep{CMS:2015dxe}
for their 13 TeV analyses as listed below. Although they have not mentioned any jet selection,
we include basic jet selection cuts in the following list to demonstrate how our signal
cut efficiencies change with different number of selected photons and jets. In Table~\ref{tab:CEhpa}
we show cut efficiencies for various selection categories for the two major contributing
$\phi$ production channels, \textit{viz.} inclusive (up to 2-jets) $pp\to \phi\gm\to 3\gm$ and
$pp\to \phi jj\to \gm\gm jj$.

\bi
\item \underline{Selection cuts for CMS 13 TeV analysis:}

\ben
\item Transverse momentum of selected photons or jets satisfy $p_T(\gm),p_T(j) > 25$ GeV
with two hardest photons satisfying $p_T(\gm_1),p_T(\gm_2) > 75$ GeV.
\item Pseudorapidity of selected photons or jets satisfy $|\eta(\gm)|,|\eta(j)|<2.5$. For
photons we exclude the barrel-endcap region by $1.44<|\eta(\gm)|<1.57$.
\item Separation in $\eta$-$\phi$ plane between any two photons or photon-jet pair
satisfies $\Dl R(\gm,\gm),\Dl R(\gm,j) > 0.4$.
\item Invariant mass of the two hardest photons satisfies $M(\gm_1,\gm_2)>230$ GeV.
\een

\item \underline{Selection cuts for ATLAS 13 TeV analysis:}

\ben
\item Transverse momentum of selected photons or jets satisfy $p_T(\gm),p_T(j) > 25$ GeV
\item Pseudorapidity of selected photons or jets satisfy $|\eta(\gm)|<2.37$ and $|\eta(j)|<2.5$.
\item Separation in $\eta$-$\phi$ plane between any two photons or photon-jet pair
satisfies $\Dl R(\gm,\gm),\Dl R(\gm,j) > 0.4$.
\item Invariant mass of the two hardest photons and their transverse momenta satisfy the
relations $p_T(\gm_1)/M(\gm_1,\gm_2)>0.4$ and $p_T(\gm_2)/M(\gm_1,\gm_2)>0.3$.
\een

\ei

\begin{table}[!ht]
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
Category & $2\gm+0j$ & $\geq 2\gm+0j$ & $2\gm+\geq 0j$ & $2\gm+1j$ & $2\gm+2j$ & $3\gm+\geq 0j$ & $\geq 2\gm+\geq 0j$\\
\hline
\hline
ATLAS ($\phi\gm$) & 0.008 & 0.278 & 0.142 & 0.057 & 0.042 & 0.641 & 0.788 \\
\hline
ATLAS ($\phi jj$) & 0.0009 & 0.001 & 0.546 & 0.030 & 0.219 & 0.010 & 0.556 \\
\hline
\hline
CMS ($\phi\gm$) & 0.036 & 0.323 & 0.247 & 0.086 & 0.063 & 0.704 & 0.957 \\
\hline
CMS ($\phi jj$) & 0.0009 & 0.001 & 0.750 & 0.035 & 0.291 & 0.013 & 0.763 \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
\caption{Cut efficiencies for different selection criteria on the number of selected photons and jets for the 13 TeV ATLAS~\cite{ATLAS:2015dxe} and CMS~\cite{CMS:2015dxe} diphoton resonance searches. Here, ``$\phi\gm$'' and ``$\phi jj$'' mean
inclusive (up to 2-jets) $pp\to \phi\gm\to 3\gm$ and $pp\to \phi jj\to \gm\gm jj$ processes respectively.}
\label{tab:CEhpa}
\end{table}

From Table~\ref{tab:CEhpa}, it is evident that the cut efficiencies are highly dependent on
the selection criteria. For example, if we demand exactly two selected photons and no selected
jet ({\it i.e.} $2\gm+0j$), the cut efficiency is 0.036 for CMS($\phi\gm$). On the other hand, this becomes 0.247 when we
select two photons and any number of jets ({\it i.e.} $2\gm+\geq 0j$). This is in contrast to the case of an $s$-channel production of SM-like
scalar decays to two photons, where we should not expect drastically different cut efficiencies
for $2\gm+0j$ and $2\gm+\geq 0j$ selection categories. In order to derive a limit on $\Lm$ by recasting the $\sg\times{\rm BR}$ upper limit from an experiment, we need to properly take care
of the cut efficiencies. This can be done by using the following relation:

\be
\label{eq:Ns}
\mc{N}_s =\sg_s\times \ep_s\times \mc{L}=\lt(\sum_i \sg_i\times\ep_i\rt)\times\mc{L}\ ,
\ee

where $\mc{N}_s$ is the number of events for the signal considered and $\sg_s$ is the
corresponding signal cross section for luminosity $\mc{L}$. The corresponding signal
cut efficiency is denoted by $\ep_s$. When different types of signal topology and/or
final state contribute to any experimental observable, $\mc{N}_s$ can be expressed by the sum
$\lt(\sum_i \sg_i\times\ep_i\rt)\times\mc{L}$. Here, $i$ runs over all contributing
signal processes to any observable. In our case, the following two processes contribute the most
to the $s$-channel diphoton resonance searches at the LHC:

\be
{\rm Process~I}~(p_1):~pp\to \phi\gm\to 3\gm+{\rm jets};~~{\rm Process~II}~(p_2):~pp\to \phi jj\to \gm\gm jj .
\ee

Therefore, in our case $\mc{N}_s=\Lm^{-2}\times(\sg_{p_1}\times\ep_{p_1}+\sg_{p_2}\times\ep_{p_2})_{\Lm=1~{\rm TeV}}\times\mc{L}$.
Here, $\sg_{p_i}$ is the signal cross section for the
$i$-th process and the corresponding signal efficiency is $\ep_{p_i}$. We briefly mention  the relevant diphoton resonance searches at the LHC. For those experiments, we also estimate the lower limit on $\Lm$
by recasting the observed upper limit on $\sg\times{\rm BR}$ with the help of the relation given in Eq.~(\ref{eq:Ns}).


Now we turn to the LHC run-I data related to the diphoton resonance searches~\cite{Khachatryan:2015qba,CMS:2015cwa,Aad:2015mna}. All these experiments search for either a spin-0 or spin-2
object produced as an $s$-channel resonance decaying to two photons.
We collect the observed upper limit on the cross sections and the corresponding efficiencies
for resonance mass around 750 GeV for each experiment. We estimate the
cut efficiencies for the processes $p_1$ and $p_2$ for these experiments by employing
selection cuts in the detector simulator {\sc Delphes3.3.1}. From this information,
one can estimate the lower limit on $\Lm$ from the formula given in Eq.~(\ref{eq:Ns}).
The overall result of the 8 TeV data of ATLAS and CMS set an upper limit of the cross section in the range 1-2 fb. Using this we can extract a lower limit of $\Lm$ for our model. This depends, however, on how the data is characterized in terms of number of photons and jets, since that affects the relevant efficiencies $\ep$. Without reporting all numerical details here, we conclude that for the interpretation of the data as $2\gm + 0j$, we obtain a lower limit of $\Lm$ in the range 0.2-0.6 TeV. Choosing instead $2\gm + \geq 0j$ would, however, give a lower limit $\Lm$ in the range 1.2-1.8 TeV.




There are two other relevant experiments at the 8 TeV LHC by ATLAS with $\mc{L}=20.3$ fb$^{-1}$ which
are important to mention in this context. In~\cite{Aad:2014ioa}, diphoton resonances are searched for, for masses up to 600 GeV for the $2\gm+0j$ category. The upper limit on the cross section is set at roughly 1~fb
around a mass of 600 GeV with cut efficiency roughly 70\%. If we assume that we get a similar upper limit on the cross section also for 750 GeV, and that the cut efficiency would remain similar, we get the lower limit, $\Lm\gtrsim 0.2$ TeV.
In~\cite{Aad:2015bua}, a triphoton resonance is searched for by ATLAS. This analysis is limited up to a
resonance mass of 500 GeV. In our model, there is a possibility of a three photon final state originating from
$pp\to \phi\gm\to 3\gm$ (although not a triphoton resonance), and therefore, triphoton resonance
searches can also be used to set limits on our model parameters in the future, if the analysis extends the resonance mass range
beyond 750 GeV.





Let us now turn to the 13 TeV data, where a more pronounced hint for an excess can give more precise information regarding our model. Following the same method as used to derive limits
on $\Lm$ from the 8 TeV data, we obtain the essential results shown in Table~\ref{tab:ltF}, resulting in 
values of $\Lm$ that can
explain the 750 GeV diphoton excesses observed by both ATLAS~\cite{ATLAS:2015dxe}
and CMS~\cite{CMS:2015dxe}. As we mentioned earlier, the extraction
of $\Lm$ depends on what selection category is used. For the
category of $2\gm + 0j$ (C1) selection for ATLAS analysis, we get $\Lm\approx 1.3$ TeV which can explain the excess. On the other hand we get slightly bigger $\Lm\approx 1.8$ TeV for the selection category
$\geq 2\gm + \geq 0j$ (C2). The corresponding CMS values on $\Lm$ are 1.4 TeV and 1.8 TeV
for C1 and C2 respectively.

\hline
Experiment & $\sg_s$ & $\ep_s$ & $\sg_{p_1}$ & $\ep_{p_1}$ & $\ep_{p_1}$ & $\sg_{p_2}$ & $\ep_{p_2}$ &
 $\ep_{p_2}$ & $\Lm$ (C1) & $\Lm$ (C2) \\
& (fb) & & (fb) & (C1) & (C2) & (fb) & (C1) & (C2) & (TeV) & (TeV) \\
\hline
ATLAS@13TeV, 3.2 fb$^{-1}$~\cite{ATLAS:2015dxe} & 10.5 & 0.4 & 9.9 & 0.14 & 0.79 & 9.7 & 0.55 & 0.56 & 1.3 & 1.8 \\
\hline
CMS@13TeV, 2.6 fb$^{-1}$~\cite{CMS:2015dxe} & 17.0 & 0.3 & 9.9 & 0.25 & 0.96 & 9.7 & 0.75 & 0.76 & 1.4 & 1.8 \\

\label{tab:ltF}
\end{table}



\section{Conclusions}
\label{sec:conclusions}

In this paper we have proposed that the diphoton excess is due to a 750 GeV scalar associated with variations of the fine-structure constant. Our proposal predicts that
the scalar dominantly decays to a photon pair, but has an appreciable branching ratio into a pair of fermions plus a photon, with BR($\phi\to\gamma q\bar q)\sim 13\%$ for quarks and BR($\phi\to\gamma\ell^+\ell^-)\sim 10\%$ for leptons. This gives the main additional prediction of our model: events with a lepton-lepton-photon resonance at 750 GeV.

The scalar resonance is dominantly produced together with an additional real or virtual photon, which, if virtual, gives rise to a pair of jets or leptons. This gives another prediction: the existence of an additional photon and/or jets in the events, which are not part of the resonance. These predictions should be looked for in future LHC analyses.

Our model has only two new parameters, the mass of the scalar $M_\phi$ and the energy scale $\Lambda$. Both are fixed by the LHC excess, with $M_{\phi}\sim 750$~GeV and $\Lambda\sim 1.5-2$~TeV.


It is interesting to note that the interaction terms for the new scalar are non-renormalizable. This means that the theory needs to be UV-completed, and as a consequence new physics is expected at the energy scale $\Lambda$. With our interpretation of the scalar as due to a moduli field parametrizing a varying electromagnetic coupling, natural candidates for this new physics are extra dimensions and possibly string theory. All of this would be within reach of the LHC.
